transcript.speaker: Speaker-2
transcript.content: This is the team. So we have 5 people on the team and there's one other part timer not listed as a data scientist, but yeah, my background Navy. Then we have a few different pH DS who are pretty strong on the physics and data science piece as well as a software engineer. So we've been.

transcript.speaker: Speaker-2
transcript.content: Yeah, Come build a team really to have kind of the technical underpinnings to do all the necessary data processing and understand kind of the underlying science behind it. So the problem we're trying to solve is space weather. So there's lots of vulnerable assets coming from space weather. It's really broadly the kind of dynamic sun Earth system where solar activity like flares, mass ejections.

transcript.speaker: Speaker-2
transcript.content: Are going to reach Earth and interact with the Earth's magnetic field.

transcript.speaker: Speaker-2
transcript.content: Upper atmosphere and they can cause a few different impacts. So some of these are listed in the diagram and some of the assets or stuff like astronauts, satellites, planes, anything using GNSS or other GNS, sorry GPS or other GNSS type systems, communication systems particularly at UHF and frequencies and lower and then also the electric grid.

transcript.speaker: Speaker-2
transcript.content: So these are just kind of a few, I guess examples of impacts from space weather events, so.

transcript.speaker: Speaker-2
transcript.content: This was a couple years ago. The SpaceX lost basically a full launch of Starling satellites because they were launched during a solar storm and these caused the satellites to become unstable, lose altitude, and ultimately come crashing back in through the atmosphere. Just this past May actually a solar storm knocked out GPS for most of America and it cost American farmers about 500 million because of the loss of revenue for being unable to use any precision.

transcript.speaker: Speaker-2
transcript.content: TPS guided agriculture equipment, and then there's also the need for astronauts as well. Where?

transcript.speaker: Speaker-2
transcript.content: Solar storms pose a major radiation threat. So they're looking at any kind of commercial or government, military, human space activity. It's solar. Solar weather is a major risk. And so that's really what we're trying to address, kind of diving into a little bit more detail on the specific impacts of space weather. So atmospheric drag, charged particle relation and ionosphere conditions are kind of a separate phenomenon, all associated with space weather, but they have different.

transcript.speaker: Speaker-2
transcript.content: So drag is really going to affect how the satellites fly through the.

transcript.speaker: Speaker-2
transcript.content: Thermosphere, so really applicable to Leo and so it's going to fly the launch operations stuff like space domain awareness and conjunction analysis and then guidance, navigation and control of satellites. So really kind of a wide range of impacts on how satellites are flying through low Earth orbit for charged particle radiation. These are going to be so high energy charge particles.

transcript.speaker: Speaker-2
transcript.content: That are coming from the sun and these can impact humans, like I said, for radiation poisoning and also satellite. So these can cause unexpected impacts on satellites and being able to kind of determine what the space environment is, is really big for anomaly resolution. So trying to determine if you know your satellite is, you know, being targeted by some type of, you know, interference and directed energy weapon or if it's just kind of a, you know, unconventional, like an unexpected space environment.

transcript.speaker: Speaker-2
transcript.content: And then also kind of for risk mitigation, so being able to assess what the space environment conditions are, kind of operate accordingly. So if you think that there's been some type of impact, you can kind of reboot, you know, your satellite and put it into essentially like a safe mode if you think that there is solar activity happening and.

transcript.speaker: Speaker-2
transcript.content: And the last one is the ionosphere. So this is really going to affect anything with signal transmission. So TNT and communications, particularly the frequencies of UHF and below can be disrupted or degraded based on space weather activities. So these are kind of some of the primary issues that we're trying to address with our platform and they have a rod a broad range of impacts both on the DoD as well as the civilian sectors.

transcript.speaker: Speaker-2
transcript.content: And so our solution is.

transcript.speaker: Speaker-2
transcript.content: Really kind of hinged on three major pillars that I briefly described earlier. So the biggest 1 is.

transcript.speaker: Speaker-2
transcript.content: Making sure that we're getting more data, so really using a lot of data processing and data fusion. So novel methods basically get more useful insights out of non traditional data sources, making sure these are efficiently processed and so we can get kind of near real time outputs. And for kind of the last, you know, missing data sources is really where we look at any of the kind of hardware type of piece of identifying that the gas once we've exhausted kind of what's available.

transcript.speaker: Speaker-2
transcript.content: And looking to kind of deploy instruments to mitigate those data gaps on the modeling side. So really what we're able to do is give higher accuracy and resolution. And also it's also applicable to forecast, kind of being able to forecast out further at at high accuracy and resolution. And so really leaning on machine learning, but physics informs, it's kind of a small subsection of the broader machine learning where we can really take advantage a lot of the known science that's driving.

transcript.speaker: Speaker-2
transcript.content: Interactions while still being able to leverage new data and kind of the modern machine learning techniques as well as some other techniques like ensemble walling and data simulation. So what we're looking at is really a lot of methods have been successfully used for terrestrial weather systems and applying these to the problem of space weather. And as mentioned the resolution or sorry the latency is something that we can really reduce as well. Machine learning models are able to run a lot faster than some of the numerical.

transcript.speaker: Speaker-2
transcript.content: Also kind of the pure physics stuff that has to be run on these massive supercomputers. So we think there's a lot of advantages in our approach. And then the last piece is really getting kind of catered insights for the different use cases to really making sure that we can meet the needs of each application. So from like risk assessments, alerts, notifications.

transcript.speaker: Speaker-2
transcript.content: Interactive kind of analytical tools, anomaly detection, and you know, having an API available to plug in the space environment into different user tools.

transcript.speaker: Speaker-2
transcript.content: So this is really all all about what we're trying to kind of do is using this and so our commercialization strategy. So really with the government looking at NASA, NOAA, DoD and the intelligence community and looking to leverage our SBIR.

transcript.speaker: Speaker-2
transcript.content: Funding so you kind of find some of these fall opportunities like the the phase three ideally would be, you know, setting up something like a a multi or an interior agency or multi agency.

transcript.speaker: Speaker-2
transcript.content: Phase three, we can address the needs of different groups.

transcript.speaker: Speaker-2
transcript.content: And then also looking at some of these matching funds opportunities as well. And then for the commercial sector, we're looking at the space industry. So satellite operator is a launch providers and different software providers for the satellites, looking at getting a pilot out there first as we're kind of developing, so getting our products in the hands of satellite operators so we can really start building those relationships in the feedback loops and also.

transcript.speaker: Speaker-2
transcript.content: Looking at doing something of a cashless exchange so we can start getting user data as well to then feed in and train our models, and then looking at doing something like a SAS revenue type model.

transcript.speaker: Speaker-2
transcript.content: Competitions, this is a little bit of the other landscape is more kind of investor focused, but there's a yes, some non traditional companies doing similar stuff. A few of the defensive crimes are also working in space weather and there's a handful of other small start-ups.

transcript.speaker: Speaker-2
transcript.content: As well. And then our funding thus far. So we do have these contracts that we're coming over from what was being worked on in the previous entities. So we have NASA SJR phase one through 3 for space weather data processing tools. We also recently started a new phase one with NASA to build a forecasting model as a machine learning model for a specific phenomena.

transcript.speaker: Speaker-2
transcript.content: We have funding from NOAA to help improve upon some of their existing tools and develop really that last mile insights of having the the monitoring, the visualizations, the alerts for, for one of the models that Noah has built. And you can kind of see not just what is the, you know, environment kind of looking at as a whole, but like what will your satellite experience specifically and kind of calculate some relative metrics like how much altitude is it going to lose based on like the expected space weather conditions.

transcript.speaker: Speaker-2
transcript.content: And so that's what we've got kind of more or less you know ready and we are at earlier stages of development and some of the other projects. transcript.speaker: Speaker-2
transcript.content: Have stuff that's really desired by the community.
